titleStmt.title: Digital Edition of Glaser Abklatsch ID: AT-OeAW-BA-3-27-A-GL1615_02
AT-OeAW-BA-3-27-A-GL1615_02

item.term: Early first millennium to the fourth century BC (predominance of Saba)
Fourth to first centuries BC (predominance of Qataban and Hadramawt, and their alliance with Main)
First century BC to early second century AD (alliances between the tribes of the high plateau and the ASA kingdoms)
Late second to late third centuries AD (wars among the Himyar, Saba and Hadramawt)
Fourth to sixth centuries AD (unification of Yemen under Himyarite rule)
It corresponds to the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans with sub-periods I-IV
First sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans
Second sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans
Second sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans
Second sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans
Third sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans
Fourth sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans
Fourth sub-period of the palaeographical divisions established by Jacques Ryckmans

graphic.desc: By kind permission of British Museum

Text preserved in this squeeze:
9.[...] Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And 10.whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and 11.goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and 12.goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with 13.any of] the tribes. And when [he establishes a shop, 14.and then sells or 15.enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and [...]
Restored full text of the inscription:
1.[Thus have ordered and decreed] 2.[and made inviolable Shahr Hilāl] 3.[bin Yadaʿʾab, King of Qatabān, and the Qa-] 4.[tabānians in Tamnaʿ and Barīm and the] 5.[two alluvial valleys of Ḥawkam and the Children of ʿAmm] 6.[and the dependents of Tamnaʿ and the dependents of the Children] 7.[of ʿAmm, that whoever should sell, in Tamnaʿ] 8.[and Barīm, any sort of merchandise, let him pay a tax] 9.[to] Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And 10.whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and 11.goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and 12.goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with 13.any of] the tribes. And when [he establishes a shop, 14.and then sells or 15.enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and [merchandise] 16.[without (the permission of) the overseer of Shammar, then] 17.[the overseer of Shammar is to take action. (It is also decreed) that the] 18.[Qatabānians shall grant hospitality to any tribes that] 19.sell in Tamnaʿ and set up a shop for its (i.e. Tamnaʿ’s) merchandise in 20.[Shammar. And may] the Qatabānians [then] buy [from the tribes and from whoever] 21.[the overseers of Shammar have taken action with respect to. (It is furthermore decreed) that] 22.[whoever among the Qatabānians has favored over the Qata-] 23.[bānians in his commercial dealings] 24.[a certain foreigner from a tribe, or has] 25.[continued to unfairly favor one individual over his fellow,] 26.[let him pay 50 silver coins to] 27.[the king of Qatabān and the overseer(s) of Shammar,] 28.[(that they might then) drop the charges(?) and resolve the matter(?)].

And when <supplied reason="lost">he establishes a shop, <lb n="14"/>and then sells or <lb n="15"/>enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and <supplied reason="lost">...</supplied>
Restored full text of the inscription:
<lb n="1"/><supplied reason="lost">Thus have ordered and decreed</supplied> <lb n="2"/><supplied reason="lost">and made inviolable Shahr Hilāl</supplied> <lb n="3"/><supplied reason="lost">bin Yadaʿʾab, King of Qatabān, and the Qa-</supplied> <lb n="4"/><supplied reason="lost">tabānians in Tamnaʿ and Barīm and the</supplied> <lb n="5"/><supplied reason="lost">two alluvial valleys of Ḥawkam and the Children of ʿAmm</supplied> <lb n="6"/><supplied reason="lost">and the dependents of Tamnaʿ and the dependents of the Children</supplied> <lb n="7"/><supplied reason="lost">of ʿAmm, that whoever should sell, in Tamnaʿ</supplied> <lb n="8"/><supplied reason="lost">and Barīm, any sort of merchandise, let him pay a tax</supplied> <lb n="9"/><supplied reason="lost">to</supplied> Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And <lb n="10"/>whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and <lb n="11"/>goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and <lb n="12"/>goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with <lb n="13"/>any of</supplied> the tribes. And when <supplied reason="lost">he establishes a shop, <lb n="14"/>and then sells or <lb n="15"/>enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and <supplied reason="lost">merchandise</supplied> <lb n="16"/><supplied reason="lost">without <unclear>the permission of</unclear> the overseer of Shammar, then</supplied> <lb n="17"/><supplied reason="lost">the overseer of Shammar is to take action. <unclear>It is also decreed</unclear> that the</supplied> <lb n="18"/><supplied reason="lost">Qatabānians shall grant hospitality to any tribes that</supplied> <lb n="19"/>sell in Tamnaʿ and set up a shop for its <unclear>i.e. Tamnaʿ’s</unclear> merchandise in <lb n="20"/><supplied reason="lost">Shammar. And may</supplied> the Qatabānians <supplied reason="lost">then</supplied> buy <supplied reason="lost">from the tribes and from whoever</supplied> <lb n="21"/><supplied reason="lost">the overseers of Shammar have taken action with respect to. <unclear>It is furthermore decreed</unclear> that</supplied> <lb n="22"/><supplied reason="lost">whoever among the Qatabānians has favored over the Qata-</supplied> <lb n="23"/><supplied reason="lost">bānians in his commercial dealings</supplied> <lb n="24"/><supplied reason="lost">a certain foreigner from a tribe, or has</supplied> <lb n="25"/><supplied reason="lost">continued to unfairly favor one individual over his fellow,</supplied> <lb n="26"/><supplied reason="lost">let him pay <lb n="50"/>silver coins to</supplied> <lb n="27"/><supplied reason="lost">the king of Qatabān and the overseer<unclear>s</unclear> of Shammar,</supplied> <lb n="28"/><supplied reason="lost"><unclear>that they might then</unclear> drop the charges<unclear>?</unclear> and resolve the matter<unclear>?</unclear></supplied>.</ab>

div.tei:ab:
Text preserved in this squeeze:
... Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And
whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and
goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and
goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with
any of the tribes. And when he establishes a shop,
and then sells or
enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and ...
Restored full text of the inscription:
Thus have ordered and decreed
and made inviolable Shahr Hilāl
bin Yadaʿʾab, King of Qatabān, and the Qa-
tabānians in Tamnaʿ and Barīm and the
two alluvial valleys of Ḥawkam and the Children of ʿAmm
and the dependents of Tamnaʿ and the dependents of the Children
of ʿAmm, that whoever should sell, in Tamnaʿ
and Barīm, any sort of merchandise, let him pay a tax
to Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And
whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and
goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and
goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with
any of the tribes. And when he establishes a shop,
and then sells or
enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and merchandise
without the permission of the overseer of Shammar, then
the overseer of Shammar is to take action. It is also decreed that the
Qatabānians shall grant hospitality to any tribes that
sell in Tamnaʿ and set up a shop for its i.e. Tamnaʿ’s merchandise in
Shammar. And may the Qatabānians then buy from the tribes and from whoever
the overseers of Shammar have taken action with respect to. It is furthermore decreed that
whoever among the Qatabānians has favored over the Qata-
bānians in his commercial dealings
a certain foreigner from a tribe, or has
continued to unfairly favor one individual over his fellow,
let him pay
silver coins to
the king of Qatabān and the overseers of Shammar,
that they might then drop the charges? and resolve the matter?.

Text preserved in this squeeze:
... Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And
whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and
goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and
goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with
any of the tribes. And when he establishes a shop,
and then sells or
enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and ...
Restored full text of the inscription:
Thus have ordered and decreed
and made inviolable Shahr Hilāl
bin Yadaʿʾab, King of Qatabān, and the Qa-
tabānians in Tamnaʿ and Barīm and the
two alluvial valleys of Ḥawkam and the Children of ʿAmm
and the dependents of Tamnaʿ and the dependents of the Children
of ʿAmm, that whoever should sell, in Tamnaʿ
and Barīm, any sort of merchandise, let him pay a tax
to Tamnaʿ and set up a shop in Shammar. And
whoever travels to the Qatabānians with merchandise and
goods and possessions, he shall have a shop and
goods, and he shall sell his wares in Shammar with
any of the tribes. And when he establishes a shop,
and then sells or
enters into a partnership with anyone possessing a stall and merchandise
without the permission of the overseer of Shammar, then
the overseer of Shammar is to take action. It is also decreed that the
Qatabānians shall grant hospitality to any tribes that
sell in Tamnaʿ and set up a shop for its i.e. Tamnaʿ’s merchandise in
Shammar. And may the Qatabānians then buy from the tribes and from whoever
the overseers of Shammar have taken action with respect to. It is furthermore decreed that
whoever among the Qatabānians has favored over the Qata-
bānians in his commercial dealings
a certain foreigner from a tribe, or has
continued to unfairly favor one individual over his fellow,
let him pay
silver coins to
the king of Qatabān and the overseers of Shammar,
that they might then drop the charges? and resolve the matter?.

bibl.seg: Avanzini, Alessandra 1995. As-Sawdāʾ. Inventaire des inscriptions sudarabiques. 4. Paris: de Boccard / Rome: Herder. [Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-lettres; Istituto italiano per l'Africa e l'Oriente]
